name: Alternate Nostril Breathing (Nadi Shodhana)
summary: A paced yogic breathing (pranayama) practice alternating airflow between nostrils to balance autonomic tone, reduce stress, and improve focus and sleep quality.
description: Alternate Nostril Breathing—known in yoga as Nadi Shodhana or Anulom Vilom—is a structured breath practice in which one nostril is gently closed while inhaling or exhaling through the other, then sides are switched in a repeating cycle. The technique emphasizes slow, even breaths and mindful attention. Physiologically, it supports parasympathetic activation, heart rate variability (HRV) improvements, reduced perceived stress, and attentional control. It is commonly taught for anxiety reduction, sleep preparation, performance calm, and adjunctive management of mild hypertension and stress-related symptoms.

treatment_variants: With kumbhaka (breath retention) for trained users
Left- or right-dominant cycles for targeted calming/alerting (traditional use)
metadata.training_required: No formal certification required; ideal with instruction from qualified yoga teacher or clinician familiar with breathwork.
metadata.regulatory_status: Not regulated; widely used as a wellness practice

contraindications: Relative: Acute/chronic nasal obstruction, active sinus infection, severe uncontrolled asthma or COPD, significant dizziness with breath practices; avoid long retentions in pregnancy or cardiovascular disease unless supervised.
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe and well-tolerated; transient lightheadedness may occur, especially with overexertion or breath-holding.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Low-to-moderate: multiple small trials and physiological studies suggest reduced anxiety, improved HRV, and modest BP effects; large RCTs are limited.

sections.text: By slowing and equalizing inhalation and exhalation while alternating nasal airflow, this practice promotes vagal tone, reduces sympathetic arousal, and can improve baroreflex sensitivity and HRV. Focused attention on the breath also recruits top-down regulatory networks that modulate limbic reactivity, supporting calm and cognitive control.

sections.preparation: Comfortable seated posture, spine tall; relaxed shoulders; clear nasal passages if possible.
procedure: Position right hand in Vishnu mudra (thumb closes right nostril; ring finger closes left).
Exhale gently through both nostrils, then close the right nostril.
Inhale through the left nostril slowly (count ~4–6).
Close left nostril; open right; exhale through right (count ~4–6).
Inhale through right; close right; exhale through left. This completes one cycle.
Continue 5–10 cycles, keeping breath smooth and comfortable. Beginners avoid breath-holds; experienced users may add light retentions (e.g., 4-4-6 or 4-4-4 ratios) if well-tolerated.
sections.frequency: 1–2 times daily; additionally before stressful events or bedtime.

items: With kumbhaka (equal or extended holds) for advanced users
Left-nostril–emphasis for calming; right-nostril–emphasis for alertness (traditional practice; variable evidence)

immediate: Sense of calm, reduced muscle tension, slower breathing
short_term: Improved sleep onset, lower perceived stress, better focus
long_term: Enhanced stress resilience, improved HRV markers, habitually calmer baseline

uncommon: Hyperventilation sensations if breathing too fast
rare: Presyncope in susceptible individuals when using prolonged breath-holds

relative: Acute sinusitis or severe nasal congestion
Cardiovascular disease: avoid intense retentions; practice gently
special_considerations: Stop if dizzy; resume with shorter, softer breaths.
Avoid forceful pressing on the nose; seal gently.

ideal_candidates: Individuals with stress, anxiety, or sleep-onset difficulty
Those seeking a nonpharmacologic relaxation tool

lifestyle_recommendations: Limit stimulants late in the day

sections.total_treatment_cost: Free; optional class/app subscriptions may apply

items: Emphasize comfort over depth—no straining or noisy breathing.
Consistency matters more than session length for lasting benefits.
If nostrils are blocked, postpone or practice gentle diaphragmatic breathing instead.
